speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about the duration of these symptoms? When did they start, and how long have you been experiencing them?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about 6 months ago, and to be honest, it's been a gradual thing. At first, I just felt a bit more tired than usual, but over time, it's gotten worse and I've lost a significant amount of weight. It's been a real challenge, to be honest, it's like I'm running on empty all the time."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so the symptoms started about 3 months ago. They've been persistent and have been getting progressively worse. Can you tell me if there's anything that might have triggered or contributed to the onset of these symptoms?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been trying to keep up with my usual routine, but I feel like I'm just not recovering as quickly as I used to. I'll be doing something for a few hours, and then I'll be exhausted afterwards, like I've overexerted myself. It's really frustrating, because I used to be able to keep up with my hobbies and activities without feeling like I need to take a nap afterwards."

speaker: Doctor
text: "When did you notice any triggers or patterns to your symptoms? For instance, do they worsen with physical activity or with certain foods?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, it seems like it's always there, but I do notice that it's worse after a long day at work or after I've been standing for a while. I've also had some days where I feel fine, but then I'll get a sudden crash and just feel completely drained. I don't think it's necessarily related to what I eat, but I have noticed that if I don't get a good night's sleep, I feel even worse the next day."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to examine you now. Please undress to your waist and put on this gown. I'll be checking your vital signs and performing a physical examination. Can you also tell me, have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, night sweats, or unexplained pain?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm ready, doctor. I'll get changed."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, thank you for undressing and putting on the gown. Let me take your vital signs. Your temperature is 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit, blood pressure is 120/80, and pulse is 72 beats per minute. I'm going to listen to your lungs and heart with the stethoscope now. Can you please place your hands behind your back so I can examine your back?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, doc, I'll do that. But just to confirm, you're not looking for anything specific with the back examination, or is it just a general check-up?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I'm going to listen to your lungs now. I don't hear any abnormalities. Your heart sounds are also normal. I'm going to examine your abdomen now, starting from the top. Can you tell me about any abdominal discomfort or pain you've been experiencing?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I've had some discomfort in my stomach, but it's more of a general feeling of emptiness or a hollow sensation, rather than sharp pain. It's hard to describe, but it's like my stomach feels a bit...drained, I suppose. It's not constant, but it comes and goes."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me if you've experienced any weight loss, particularly in the last few months? Was it a gradual loss or more sudden?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I've lost about 18.1 kg over the past 6 months. It's been a gradual loss, but it's been steady and noticeable, and it's been a challenge to keep up with my usual weight. I feel like I'm losing muscle mass, too, because I can feel it when I look in the mirror."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Great, thank you for the information. I'm going to request a complete blood count and basic metabolic panel to get a better understanding of your overall health. Can you tell me, have you traveled recently or had any exposure to anyone who's been sick recently?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I've actually been thinking about that, doc. I have a few colleagues who've been going through some health issues lately, but I don't think any of them have been contagious. As for traveling, I did take a trip to my hometown about a month ago, but I didn't notice anything out of the ordinary. I did have a bit of a scare when I was there, though - I had to visit my parents, and my mom was in the hospital for a few days. But I'm pretty sure she's okay now."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about your diet and eating habits over the past few months? Have you noticed any changes or patterns in your appetite, or have you been experiencing any gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea or constipation?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I've been trying to stick to my usual routine, but I think I've lost a bit of my appetite over the past few months. I used to enjoy eating, but now I find myself not really craving certain foods like I used to. I've also been having trouble keeping up with my usual portion sizes, which is probably contributing to the weight loss. It's like my stomach feels...sensitive, I guess, when I eat, like it's not digesting food properly or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me, have you experienced any difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, even at rest?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I have had some trouble catching my breath after I've been standing for a while, or after I've exerted myself. It's like my body is working harder than it should be, and I feel like I'm not getting enough oxygen. It's really frustrating, because I'll be doing something simple, like taking a shower or getting dressed, and I'll feel like I'm going to pass out from lack of breath."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to examine your head and neck now. Can you please turn your head to the left and right, and also tilt your head back so I can look at the back of your throat?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"Okay, doc, I'll do that. But just to confirm, you're not looking for anything specific with the neck examination, or is it just a general check-up?"

"Let's start with the left side, please. Can you turn your head to the left and look up towards the ceiling. I'm just checking for any swelling or tenderness in the lymph nodes."

"Okay, I'm doing that. It feels a bit stiff, but I don't notice anything out of the ordinary. It's not painful, just a bit tight."

"Alright, now let's switch to the right side. Can you turn your head to the right and look down towards your chest? I want to check for any swelling or tenderness in the neck lymph nodes again."

"Okay, I'm doing that. It's still a bit stiff, but I don't feel anything unusual. It's just a bit sore, I suppose."

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to request an ECG to get a more detailed look at your heart rhythm and see if there's any abnormality. Also, can you tell me more about your sleep patterns over the past few months, have you noticed any changes in the quality or duration of your sleep?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I've noticed that I've been having trouble sleeping a lot more than I used to. I'll fall asleep fine, but then I'll wake up multiple times during the night and not be able to fall back asleep. It's like my body is just not resting properly, you know? And I wake up feeling really tired, like I've been up for hours even though I've only been asleep for a few hours."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Thank you for your thorough responses. I'd like to examine your lymph nodes now. Can you slowly open your mouth for me so I can take a look?



Also, I'd like to request an imaging study, can you please answer yes or no: Have you recently traveled to any foreign countries?



And one more thing, have you noticed any changes in your urination habits or are you experiencing any pain or discomfort while urinating?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"Okay, doc, I've slowly opened my mouth. I'm ready for the lymph node examination."

"No, I haven't traveled to any foreign countries recently. I've been pretty much staying within the country for the past few months."

"No, I don't have any issues with urination. I do have to get up multiple times during the night, though. I'll get up and go to the bathroom, and I feel like I'm not emptying my bladder properly, like there's still some liquid left in there."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for your responses. I'd like to examine your lymph nodes more closely. I see that they're slightly enlarged, but I'll need to get a more precise measurement to determine if this is significant. I'll take some notes and we can discuss this further. Can you tell me, have you noticed any lymph nodes in your neck that are particularly tender or swollen?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I have noticed that one of them feels a bit tender to the touch, but it's not extremely painful. It's more of a...a dull ache, I suppose. It's not noticeable, but it's definitely there."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, thank you for your detailed responses. I'd like to take a closer look at your enlarged lymph nodes. I'm going to gently press on them to assess their tenderness. Can you hold still for just a moment while I do this.

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, doc, I'll hold still. I'm a bit nervous, but I trust you'll know what you're doing."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about your social life, have you been around anyone who's been sick, such as a family member or roommate?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been pretty much staying at home since I've been feeling this way, to be honest. I don't want to risk getting anyone else sick, but it's also been hard to keep up with my social life because I'm just not feeling well enough. I've been trying to stay connected with friends and family through phone calls and video chats, but it's just not the same as being there in person."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"I'd like to examine your lymph nodes more closely. I see that they're slightly enlarged, but I'll need to get a more precise measurement to determine if this is significant. Can you hold still for just a moment while I take some notes. I'm also going to check your spleen for any tenderness or abnormalities. 

Can you take a deep breath in and out slowly and hold it for a second, and then exhale slowly. I'm going to listen to your lungs again to see if there's any change in your lung sounds."

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, doc, I'll do that. *takes a deep breath in, holds it for a second, and exhales slowly* Ah, I feel a bit more relaxed now. Go ahead and examine the lymph nodes again."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for taking deep breaths and holding it for a second. I'm going to listen to your lungs again and I don't hear any changes. I'm going to check your spleen for any tenderness or abnormalities. Can you tell me, have you noticed any night sweats, which are excessive sweating at night that's not related to the heat or exercise?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I haven't noticed any night sweats. I do tend to sweat a lot when I'm hot or exercising, but I don't have any night sweats. I've been trying to keep my bedroom cool and comfortable, but I don't think that's the issue. I do get hot flashes, though, when I'm standing or exerting myself, but they're not related to the night, I think."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for taking deep breaths and holding it for a second. I'm going to check your spleen for any tenderness or abnormalities. I do notice that your spleen is slightly tender to the touch. I'm going to request an ultrasound to get a more detailed look at your spleen and lymph nodes. Can you tell me, have you noticed any fever, chills, or general feeling of illness, such as a cold or flu, in addition to your fatigue and malaise?"

speaker: Patient
text:
"Actually, I've had a few days where I've felt a bit unwell, but it's hard to pinpoint exactly what's causing it. I think it's more of a general feeling of being off, rather than anything specific. But I do remember one time when I was standing in line at the grocery store, and I felt really lightheaded and dizzy, and I had to sit down to catch my breath. It was a pretty intense feeling, but it's not something that happens often."

"Okay, I see. I'd like to examine your liver and gallbladder now. Can you tell me if you've noticed any discomfort or pain in those areas?"

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for your thorough responses. Based on the information you've provided, I've made some observations and noted several areas of concern. I'm going to request a biopsy of the enlarged lymph nodes to get a more definitive diagnosis. I'm also going to request a complete blood count, basic metabolic panel, and liver function tests to rule out any underlying conditions. I'd like to review the test results with you and discuss the next steps in your care. Can you please wait here for a few minutes while I prepare for the biopsy and review the test results?"
